prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Red sample
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Sources with UV slope, beta ~-1. These are bright sources with flux densities at 350 GHz expected to be >750 uJy.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our goal is to obtain continuum observations, we do not have requirements on spectral resolution, and our required data rates are minimal.
Sources are ~1 arcsec in size in UV. 400 mas resolution is ideal to exploit synergy with HST imaging of the sources in the rest-UV and explore offsets or size differences.

The expected flux density assumes these galaxies follow the lower redshift Meurer relation. Recent results suggest higher-z galaxies may be fainter in the FIR. The Required sensitivity makes provisions to detect these galaxies even if they were 5 times fainter individually (3 sigma), and ~10 times fainter by combining their images.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Intermediate sample
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Sources with UV slope, beta ~-1.5. These sources have expected flux densities at 350 GHz expected of 300-800 uJy.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our goal is to obtain continuum observations, we do not have requirements on spectral resolution, and our required data rates are minimal.
Sources are ~1 arcsec in size in UV. 400 mas resolution is ideal to exploit synergy with HST imaging of the sources in the rest-UV and explore offsets or size differences.

The expected flux density assumes these galaxies follow the lower redshift Meurer relation. Recent results suggest higher-z galaxies may be fainter in the FIR. The Required sensitivity makes provisions to detect these galaxies even if they were 3 times fainter individually (3 sigma), and ~8 times fainter by combining their images.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Blue sample
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Sources with UV slope, beta ~-2. These are faint sources with flux densities at 350 GHz expected to be 80-100 uJy.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our goal is to obtain continuum observations, we do not have requirements on spectral resolution, and our required data rates are minimal.
Sources are ~1 arcsec in size in UV. 400 mas resolution is ideal to exploit synergy with HST imaging of the sources in the rest-UV and explore offsets or size differences.

The expected flux density assumes these galaxies follow the lower redshift Meurer relation. Recent results suggest higher-z galaxies may be fainter in the FIR. We have positioned 4 sources in 3 pointings. If sources were much fainter 8 times fainter than expected we should still have 2 sigma detection on the stack of four sources.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Today we have detailed UV and optical observations of thousands of z>4 galaxies from which we have studied galaxy mass buildup through SED modeling. Whereas stellar mass estimates typically have factor 2x uncertainties, the star formation rate (SFR) has associated systematic uncertainties of >10x, chiefly driven by uncertain dust attenuation corrections. Independent estimates of dust attenuation require measuring the far infrared (FIR) luminosity of galaxies, which has been out of reach for normal star forming galaxies at z>3. Hence, we have relied in local relations like the IRX-beta to estimate dust attenuation from UV colors. Here we propose to improve this situation by making deep FIR observations of 9 galaxies at z~5. Our sample spans a wide range of UV continuum slopes (beta ~ -1.0 -2.1), corresponding to a wide range of dust extinction values. From these observations we expect to estimate total FIR luminosities, obtain IRX-beta relations at high-z, and test different dust extinction curves (e.g., Calzetti, SMC). ALMA has the unique capabilities to do this at very high-z and significantly improve in one of the most significant uncertainties in high-z SED modeling.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
